result.markdown:
--- title: "Time Series Lag Correlation Plots" author: "Steven P. Sanderson II, MPH" date: "2022-11-11" categories: [code, rtip, healthyrts, weeklytip] image: healthyrts_logo.png --- # Introduction In time series analysis there is something called a lag. This simply means we take a look at some past event from some point in time *t*. This is a non-statistical method for looking at a relationship between a timeseries and its lags. [`{healthyR.ts}`](https://www.spsanderson.com/healthyR.ts/) has a function called [`ts_lag_correlation()`](https://www.spsanderson.com/healthyR.ts/reference/ts_lag_correlation.html). This function, as described by it's name, provides more than just a simple lag plot. This function provides a lot of extra information for the end user. First let's go over the function call. # Function ## Function Call Here is the full call: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ts_lag_correlation( .data, .date_col, .value_col, .lags = 1, .heatmap_color_low = "white", .heatmap_color_hi = "steelblue" ) ``` ::: Here are the arguments that get supplied to the different parameters. - `.data` - A tibble of time series data - `.date_col` - A date column - `.value_col` - The value column being analyzed - `.lags` - This is a vector of integer lags, ie 1 or c(1,6,12) - `.heatmap_color_low` - What color should the low values of the heatmap of the correlation matrix be, the default is **'white'** - `.heatmap_color_hi` - What color should the low values of the heatmap of the correlation matrix be, the default is **'steelblue'** ## Function Return The function itself returns a list object. The list has the following elements in it: _Data Elements_ * `lag_list` * `lag_tbl` * `correlation_lag_matrix` * `correlation_lag_tbl` _Plot Elements_ * `lag_plot` * `plotly_lag_plot` * `correlation_heatmap` * `plotly_heatmap` # Example Let's take a look at an example. We are going to use the built in data set of __AirPassengers__. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(healthyR.ts) library(dplyr) df <- ts_to_tbl(AirPassengers) %>% select(-index) lags <- c(1,3,6,12) output <- ts_lag_correlation( .data = df, .date_col = date_col, .value_col = value, .lags = lags ) ``` ::: Now that we have our output, let's examine each piece of it. ## Data Elements Here are the data elements. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$data$lag_list ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [[1]] # A tibble: 143 × 3 lag value lagged_value 1 1 118 112 2 1 132 118 3 1 129 132 4 1 121 129 5 1 135 121 6 1 148 135 7 1 148 148 8 1 136 148 9 1 119 136 10 1 104 119 # … with 133 more rows [[2]] # A tibble: 141 × 3 lag value lagged_value 1 3 129 112 2 3 121 118 3 3 135 132 4 3 148 129 5 3 148 121 6 3 136 135 7 3 119 148 8 3 104 148 9 3 118 136 10 3 115 119 # … with 131 more rows [[3]] # A tibble: 138 × 3 lag value lagged_value 1 6 148 112 2 6 148 118 3 6 136 132 4 6 119 129 5 6 104 121 6 6 118 135 7 6 115 148 8 6 126 148 9 6 141 136 10 6 135 119 # … with 128 more rows [[4]] # A tibble: 132 × 3 lag value lagged_value 1 12 115 112 2 12 126 118 3 12 141 132 4 12 135 129 5 12 125 121 6 12 149 135 7 12 170 148 8 12 170 148 9 12 158 136 10 12 133 119 # … with 122 more rows ``` ::: ::: This is a list of all the tibbles of the different lags that were chosen. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$data$lag_tbl ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 554 × 4 lag value lagged_value lag_title 1 1 118 112 Lag: 1 2 1 132 118 Lag: 1 3 1 129 132 Lag: 1 4 1 121 129 Lag: 1 5 1 135 121 Lag: 1 6 1 148 135 Lag: 1 7 1 148 148 Lag: 1 8 1 136 148 Lag: 1 9 1 119 136 Lag: 1 10 1 104 119 Lag: 1 # … with 544 more rows ``` ::: ::: This is the long lag `tibble` with all of the lags in it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$data$correlation_lag_matrix ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` value value_lag1 value_lag3 value_lag6 value_lag12 value 1.0000000 0.9542938 0.8186636 0.7657001 0.9905274 value_lag1 0.9542938 1.0000000 0.8828054 0.7726530 0.9492382 value_lag3 0.8186636 0.8828054 1.0000000 0.8349550 0.8218493 value_lag6 0.7657001 0.7726530 0.8349550 1.0000000 0.7780911 value_lag12 0.9905274 0.9492382 0.8218493 0.7780911 1.0000000 ``` ::: ::: This is the correlation matrix. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$data$correlation_lag_tbl ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 25 × 3 name data_names value 1 value value 1 2 value_lag1 value 0.954 3 value_lag3 value 0.819 4 value_lag6 value 0.766 5 value_lag12 value 0.991 6 value value_lag1 0.954 7 value_lag1 value_lag1 1 8 value_lag3 value_lag1 0.883 9 value_lag6 value_lag1 0.773 10 value_lag12 value_lag1 0.949 # … with 15 more rows ``` ::: ::: This is the correlation lag `tibble` ## Plot Elements ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$plots$lag_plot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The Lag Plot itself. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$plots$plotly_lag_plot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: A plotly version of the lag plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$plots$correlation_heatmap ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: A heatmap of the correlations. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} output$plots$plotly_heatmap ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: A plotly version of the correlation heatmap. _Voila!_
